In 2011, Luisito joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his business and living situation. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for his bicycle.

location.town: Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy bales of wheat flour, cooking fat, maize flour, and repair one of her rental houses.

loans.name: Wesakulila Group

texts.en:
Wilfred is the facilitator of the Wesakulila group. Wilfred and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Wilfred takes care of eight children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Wilfred had an excellent maize yield harvesting 7 ½ bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Wilfred was only able to harvest 3 ½ bags of maize on ½  acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Wilfred and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Wilfred will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Wesakulila group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Wilfred is pictured with his group members, and the field officer is standing on the far left.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Lyda's Group

texts.en:
Lyda is a 29-year-old mother of two children who are too young to attend school. She is a farmer in a rural area where the typical business is rice farming. She has been farming on her farmland for almost eleven years to earn a living. To better feed her family, she also raises pigs in the back yard of her house. Her husband is a worker. With her current business, she earns less than 6 US dollars per day.
 
Lyda leads a group of two female members. She and the other member of her group have been with VisionFund for one year and three years, respectively.
 
After her first loan cycle with VisionFund, Lyda can afford enough food to feed her children. Now she is applying for another loan. She will use this loan to pay others to harvest her rice crops.
 
She hopes to have more rice to sell for a good price so as to earn more income.  She plans to set aside some money to send her children to school.

loans.use: to pay for labor in harvesting.

loans.name: Thim

texts.en:
Thim, 62, is married and resides with her husband in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. Thim and her husband are farmers. 

Thim is requesting a loan of $1,200 to open a food store for her daughter. This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to open a food store for her daughter.

loans.name: Mo'tasem

texts.en: Mo'tasem is a 28-year-old young married man. He has a cafe with pool tables and also works in installing air conditioning to improve his income. Mo'tasem wants to expand his cafe by purchasing additional pool tables, but he does not have enough money for the purchase, so he needs to take out a loan in the amount of $3,000 from FATEN. When Mo'tasem gets the loan, he will purchase additional pool tables. This will increase the number of tables he has in the cafe, so his customers will increase and his income will increase too. He will be able to provide better living conditions for his family. Mo'tasem is photographed next to the pool table he has in the cafe.

loans.use: To purchase pool tables

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna is from the village of Militar, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 41 years old. Lorna is married and has five school-aged children. 

To make a living, Lorna owns and operates a pedicab transport service. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month for these activities. 

In 2009, Lorna joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorna is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase spare parts for the pedicab. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for the pedicab.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to increase grocery stock.

loans.name: Houenoussou Group

texts.fr: Le groupement HOUENOUSSOU est formé de treize personnes qui résident dans le même village et appartiennent à un même groupe de tontine. La représentante de ce groupe, nommée Brigitte est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. Brigitte est âgée de 37 ans, et est mariée à un enseignant du nom de Florent. Le couple a cinq enfants, tous scolarisés dont trois à leur charge. Brigitte n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Depuis une quinzaine d’année, Brigitte vend des charbon de bois et de l'huile de palme qu'elle produit dans sa région. Cette activité lui génère des revenus lui permettant d’assurer ensemble avec son mari les diverses charges de la famille. Brigitte achète ses produits dans un village du Bénin et les revend dans sa région. C’est la troisième fois que Brigitte et les autres membres du groupement HOUENOUSSOU sollicitent un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Ce crédit leur permettra de renforcer leur activité et d'accroître leur fonds de roulement, afin de mieux répondre à la demande de leur clientèle.
texts.en:
The Houenoussou group consists of thirteen persons residing in the same village and belonging to the same tontine (revolving savings and loan group). The representative of the group, named Brigitte, is the one whose hand is raised in the photo.

Brigitte is 37 years old and is married to a teacher named Florent. The couple has five children, of whom three are dependents. All attend (or have attended) school. Brigitte has not attended school herself.

For the past fifteen years, Brigitte has been selling throughout her region the charcoal and palm oil she produces. This activity generates sufficient revenue to manage together with her husband all the various family expenses. Brigitte resupplies from a village in Benin and sells her products in the surrounding area.

This is the third time that Brigitte and other members of the Houenoussou group have sought a credit loan from ALIDé. This loan will allow them to strengthen their business and increase their working capital, in order to better meet the needs of their customers.

loans.use: Buy palm nuts.

loans.name: Huruma B Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Huruma B group in Western Kenya! Alice is the facilitator of the Huruma B group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Alice takes care of 10 children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Alice had a very good maize yield, harvesting 16 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Alice was only able to harvest 6 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Alice and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Alice will educate her children and ensure food security.

In 2012, the members of Huruma B group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

The photograph shows Alice with her group members; standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Cheam

texts.en:
Mrs. Cheam works in a garment factory as a sewing worker. She has been engaged in this business since early 2011. She usually gets a monthly salary of approximately $80.  

At the age of 32, she is the mother of one child who is attending school. Her husband is a construction foreman, working in mobile places around the country. 

With the sum of KHR4,500,000, she will buy stock of cashew fruits from local villagers, and then she will continue selling them to tradesmen at a profitable price. In the future, she wants to decorate and fix her present house partially.

loans.use: to buy stock of cashew fruits from local villagers.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is 28 years old, married to Catherine and they have one child who is two years old. He has been running a retail shop for the past six months, earning an income of KES.10,000 a month.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by a credit officer and this is his first loan from KADET LTD. He will use the entire loan to buy bales of wheat flour, cooking fat, maize flour and detergent for sale.

He will use the anticipated profits to provide for his family's basic needs. He hopes to grow his business and to own a wholesale shop in the future.

loans.use: to buy bales of wheat flour, cooking fat, maize flour and detergent for sale

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en: Hellen is a single lady with two children aged fourteen and ten who she hopes to educate to university level. She owns a banana sales store in an area that is densely populated. She has been running her business for the past five years and has hired two employees. She says the business is profitable and her only major challenge is insufficient capital. She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to increase her stock of bananas. She hopes to grow her business to a wholesale operation in the next five years. She describes herself as honest.

loans.use: To pay rent for a banana storage store.

loans.name: Jipange Women Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Jipange Women Group in Western Kenya! Esther is the facilitator of the Jipange Women group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Esther takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to have additional maize profits to educate her children and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Esther had an excellent maize yield, harvesting 23 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Esther was only able to harvest 7 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Esther and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Esther will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Jipange Women group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

The photograph shows Esther with her group members and standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Douglas

texts.en:
Douglas is a 44-year-old business man. He is married to Elizabeth who is a housewife. He has been a lab technician for the past three years earning a monthly income of KES 8,000 which he uses to support his family.

He is applying for his first loan from KADET LTD after being introduced by a KADET staff member. Douglas will use the loan to buy chemicals and medicines for his business. 

With the anticipated profit from the business he will educate his children. His hopes and dreams are to open a chemist which will help him to improve the living standard of his family.

loans.use: To buy chemicals and medicines for the laboratory

loans.name: Ushindi Shg Group

texts.en:
Bridgit is the facilitator of the Ushindi SHG group. Bridgit and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Bridgit and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Bridgit joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Bridgit had an excellent maize yield, harvesting 16 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Bridgit was only able to harvest 6 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With income from maize sales, Bridgit will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing for future use.

In 2012, the members of Ushindi SHG group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

The photograph shows Bridgit pictured with her group members and standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Rehana's Group

texts.en:
Rehana has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah in order to improve her husband’s tailoring business. With the loan, he will buy a new sewing machine to improve his business. He will also hire a worker who will assist him in his work.

He is a very talented person and receives a good number of orders every month due to his good quality work. He can sew shalwar kameez (traditional garments of South and Central Asia), pants, and shirts of different styles, and charges very reasonable rates for his services.

Rehana is also a seamstress and sews clothes for her neighboring female clients. She started this business to support her husband financially.

She is the mother of four children, all of whom stay at home and don’t do anything.

She is very hopeful that after investing the loan, her husband will be able to gain larger profits and she will be able to send her younger children to school for education.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine for her husband's tailoring business.

loans.name: Leria

texts.en:
This is Leria, 55, a resident of Tanza, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Vergilio, a businessman, and is mother to their children. She, together with her husband and children, manage their own household while operating the business. She works hard to provide income for their everyday expenses.

Leria operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 400 in sales every day.

To help her business, she is requesting a Php 12,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Leria hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she hopes that her business will be able to sustain the needs of her family. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy stock for her store

loans.name: Sedjro Group

texts.fr: SEDJRO est un groupement constitué de quatorze personnes et dont la  présidente (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) se nomme Mélanie Judith. Les membres du groupe résident dans le même village et exercent leurs activités dans un même marché. Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de roulement, ce groupement sollicite pour la deuxième fois, un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Mélanie Judith est âgée de 45 ans et vit au  Bénin avec sa famille. Mélanie Judith est mariée à un maçon du nom de Casmir. Le couple a six enfants, tous scolarisés, dont trois à leur charge. Mélanie Judith et son mari subviennent ensemble aux différents besoins de la famille. Mélanie Judith n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Depuis une quinzaine d'année, Mélanie Judith mène comme activité la vente de divers produits (sel de cuisine, huile végétale, etc.) et des plastiques de façon secondaire. Mélanie Judith achète ses produits dans une ville du Bénin et les revend dans sa région. Ce deuxième prêt permettra certainement à Mélanie Judith et aux autres membres du groupement SEDJRO, de rehausser le niveau de leur activité et d’accroître leur clientèle et leur revenu.
texts.en: SEDJRO is a group consisting of fourteen people, whose leader (with her hand raised in the photograph) is Mélanie Judith. The group members live in the same village and conduct their trading in the same marketplace. In order to increase their working capital, this group is requesting a second loan with ALIDé. Mélanie Judith is 45 years old and lives in Benin with her family. Mélanie Judith is married to a mason called Casmir. The couple have six children, all school educated, three of whom still live at home. Mélanie Judith and her husband work together in meeting the various needs of the family. Mélanie Judith did not go to school. For about fifteen years, Mélanie Judith has been a trader of various products (table salt, vegetable oil, etc) and plastic goods on a smaller scale. Mélanie Judith buys her products in a town in Benin and resells them in her region. This second loan will certainly allow Mélanie Judith, and all the members of the SEDJRO group, to increase their business and to grow their customer base and their income.

loans.use: To buy various products (vegetable oil, plastic goods etc)

loans.name: Mwibo Youth Group

texts.en:
Mary is the facilitator of the Mwibo Youth group. Mary and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Mary takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for her family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, she had an excellent maize yield, harvesting 17 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Mary was only able to harvest 10 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Mary and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Mary will educate her children, build a house and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Mwibo Youth group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

Mary is pictured in the photograph with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Samuel Mwiti

texts.en: Samuel is married and has a two year old son. He describes himself as an ambitious man. He has been selling drinks for the past five years. His main business challenge is increased transportation costs. He will use the loan of Kes20,000 to buy stock of soft drinks.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks.

loans.name: Reem

texts.en: Reem is a 36-year-old woman. She is married and has five sons and two daughters. Her husband is a taxi driver with a decent salary. Reem wants to help her husband to insure and license his taxi, but she doesn't have the money, so she needs to take a loan of amount $1,000 from FATEN. When Reem gets the loan, she will help her husband to pay for insuring and licensing his taxi. This will make the taxi legal to operate, allowing her husband to work extra hours and take more internal and external requests. This will increase his income and enable him to provide better living conditions for the family. Reem and her husband are photographed next to the taxi.

loans.use: To pay for insuring and licensing her husband's taxi.

loans.name: Kunihira

texts.en:
Kunihira is a 42-year-old married woman with eight children living in a semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. Her family goal is to educate her children to higher levels. 

She sells old clothes and has been in this business for 18 years; she started with 200,000 shillings but now it's worth 1,500,000 shillings as working capital. She faces a challenge of seasonal changes in the weather. 

Kunihira needs the loan to buy women's clothes for selling this Christmas season.

loans.use: to buy women's clothes for selling this Christmas season.

loans.name: Srey's Group

texts.en:
Srey is a 41-year-old farmer in a rural area of Thmor Koul district, where the typical business is rice farming. She has two children and her oldest daughter works at the rice field while her youngest son is still in school. She has been farming on her farmland for almost 20 years to make a living. She now earns $5 per day to feed her family, and she has less than $1.50 for her savings.

Srey leads a group of two female members. She and her group member have been with VisionFund for two loan cycles and completely repaid the last loan with VisionFund. After her first loan, she can afford enough food for her family and send her son to school. She is now requesting another loan. She will use this loan to buy fertilizer for her farmland and use some to renovate her house.

With this loan, she hopes to increase her crop yield and sell for a good price so as to set aside some savings for future needs and keep her son in school.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farmland.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice is married and has two children. She describes herself as ambitious. She has been running a grocery store for the past eight years. Her business is faced with the problem of increased price of goods. She will be using the loan of Kes 20,000 to add stock to her store. She looks forward to expanding her business in the future.

loans.use: To add stock to her grocery shop.

loans.name: Lorana

texts.en:
This is Lorna, 61, a resident of Tanza, Cavite, Philippines. Her husband is Miguel who is retired from the navy. She and her husband manage their household and operate the business. She works hard to provide income for their everyday expenses.  

Lorna operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php600 in sales every day.

To help her business, she is requesting a Php 11,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory and to pay for maintenance of her sewing machine. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Lorna hopes her business will grow into a mini grocery. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed for her business.

loans.name: Jovanis

texts.en: Jovanis is a 47-year-old widow living in Fort Portal, Uganda. She operates a used-clothes business. She has progressed from her starting capital of eight hundred thousand to its current value of two million. She faces the challenges of customers not paying on time and inadequate capital to purchase stock. Her dream is to educate her children. Her business dream is set up a boutique in her town. Jovanis needs the loan to buy women's and children's clothes to sell.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen is a 51-year-old married man living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He owns a shop where he sells clothes. He started out in farming where he raised the capital to start the shop, which has since progressed. He faces the challenges of price fluctuations, inflation and the seasonal nature of the business. His dream is to educate his children and to build a permanent home. Stephen needs the loan to buy first class clothes to sell this Christmas season.

loans.use: to buy first class clothes to sell.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles a 29-year-old man living in Bundibugyo, Uganda. He is married and has one child. He owns a music library in his town. His personal goals are to have a good looking, permanent house for his family and to educate himself. His business is going well despite the hindrances of inadequate capital and unpredictable customers. Charles needs the loan to purchase tapes, DVDs, CDs and videos.

loans.use: to purchase tapes, DVDs, CDs and videos

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 48 years old. He is married to Charity, and they have two children who are in school. He has been in the transportation business as his primary business for the last 15 years, and he also practices farming. He has an income of 15,000 KES a month.

This is his fifth loan from KADET LTD, and he will use the loan to service his pick-up truck and to buy some farm supplies.

He will use the anticipated profits to provide for his family’s basic needs. He hopes to grow his business and to own a fleet of vehicles.

loans.use: to service his pick-up truck and to buy some farm supplies.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase tomatoes,oranges,cabbages and carrots

loans.name: Umoja Group

texts.en:
Agnettah is the facilitator of the Umoja group. Agnettah and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Agnettah and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

She joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough to ensure food security for her family and the community and to have additional maize profits to educate her children. In the recent 2011 season, Agnettah had an excellent maize yield harvesting 16 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Agnettah was only able to harvest eight bags of maize on one acre of land. With income from maize sales, Agnettah will save for the future and educate her children.

In 2012, the members of Umoja group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

The photograph shows Agnettah with her group members and the field officer who is standing on the far left.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Jazhem

texts.en:
This is Jazhem, 29, resident of Tanza, Cavite, Philippines. He is married to Melissa, a housewife and mother to their child – who is in grade school. Jazhem, together with his wife and child, manage their own household while operating the business. At this time, he is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses and support his child’s schooling. 

Jazhem operates a food stall wherein he sells fish balls. In the Philippines, fish balls are commonly sold on street sides; it is served skewered and can be dipped with different kinds of sauces. Fish balls are somewhat flat in shape and often made with the meat of a cuttlefish. His other products include squid balls and quail eggs.  His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. He earns a minimum of Php 200 in sales every day.

To help him continue operations of his business, Jazhem is requesting a Php 9,000 loan. He will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of fish ball products and other ingredients needed in his business. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands her business.

Jazhem hopes to be able to expand soon, just as he fervently hopes that his child will be able graduate one day. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional fish ball products and other ingredients needed in his business.

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.en:
Jacinta is  48 years old, married to Moses and blessed with four children. She is a tailor in the area of Maji Mazuri in Nairobi where she has her tailoring business. She has been in this business for the last 12 years and gets an income of KES.23,800 per month.


Jacinta has a good credit history with KADET LTD and she is applying for her third loan of KES.50,000 from KADET LTD with which she plans to buy tailoring materials like bolts of cloth. She will use the extra profit to pay school fees.

Jacinta hopes to establish her business and to educate her children to tertiary level.She is very hardworking and focused.

loans.use: To buy bolts of cloth for making dresses.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cosmetics

loans.name: Artur

texts.en: Artur trades in clothing and household goods from a rented booth in a city market. Artur needs some financial investments in order to expand his business. With the requested loan Artur plans to purchase more goods to sell. Increasing the product variety will allow Artur to improve his business's income. This will help Artur to improve his family's living conditions and ensure a sustainable future for them. Artur lives with his wife and two daughters.

loans.use: to buy clothing and household goods to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase three cattle.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph used the previous loan to buy  cows to butcher. However he faces challenges of price fluctuations and inflation.His personal goals are educating his children and building a permanent home.His business goal is to buy land and grow crops for sale .Joseph needs the loan to buy cows to butcher this Christmas season.

loans.use: to buy  cows to butcher this Christmas season

loans.name: Chorn

texts.en: Mrs. Chorn is 45 years old. She lives with her husband and two children in Kompong Cham Province in Cambodia. She is a responsible housewife who always takes care of the family, in addition to her farming work. She grows an annual rice crop alongside her husband on her own farmland. Agriculture is the sole source of her income. Currently, one of her daughters is involved in a used clothing business, which can generate additional profits for the family. In order to sustain this new business, Mrs. Chorn is applying for a loan from HKL and Kiva to purchase a stock of used clothes for her daughter. Mrs. Chorn hopes that she will be able to improve her standard of living as she gains more profits through the use of this loan.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of used clothes for her daughter's used clothing business.

loans.name: Koeun

texts.en:
Koeun is a 31-year-old farmer who also catches fish for sale. He has two children who are too young to attend school. He started farming on his farmland nearly ten years ago. He earns less than 11 US dollars per day to feed his family and he can save about 2 US dollars per day for unexpected expenses. 

This is his second loan with VisionFund. He completely repaid his first loan. Now he is requesting another loan to buy rice seeds for his farmland. 

He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase crop yield, to sell at a good price and earn more income to build up some savings for his family.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds for his farmland

loans.name: Joefrey

texts.en:
This is Joefrey, 43, a resident of Tanza, Cavite, Philippines. He is married to Loleta, a housewife and mother to their four children. He, along with his wife and children, manages their household while operating the business. He works hard to provide income for their everyday expenses and to support his children’s schooling.

Joefrey operates a food stall where he sells fish balls. In the Philippines, fish balls are commonly sold on street sides; they are served skewered and can be dipped in different kinds of sauces. Fish balls are somewhat flattened in shape and often made with cuttlefish meat. His other products include squid balls and quail eggs. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. He earns a minimum of Php 200 in sales every day.

To help him continue operating his business, he is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. He will use the loan to buy more quantities of fish ball products and other ingredients needed in his business. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands the business.

Joefrey hopes to be able to expand soon, just as he fervently hopes that his children will be able to finish their studies. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional stock of fish ball products and other ingredients

loans.name: Expedith

texts.en: Expedith is 29 years old and single. He sells fertilizers in a shop that he has run for 6 years, but he would like a loan to buy veterinary products such as injections, capsules and aerosols to sell in his store. He will use any profits to build a house.

loans.use: To buy veterinary products to sell in his store

loans.name: Narcisse

texts.en: Narcisse is 32 years old and single. He owns a general store which he has been running for several years. He would like a loan to buy items such as maize flour, beans, cooking oil, and sorghum to sell in his store. Narcisse will use any profits to put towards building a house.

loans.use: To buy more cooking oil, sorghum and maize flour for sell

loans.name: Beathe

texts.en: Beathe is 53 years old with 6 children aged 12 to 24. She has been running a business selling foodstuffs for 15 years. She would like a loan to buy more sugar, bread and rice to sell in her store. Any profits will be used to pay school fees for her children and to save for her future.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, bread and rice to sell

loans.name: Francine

texts.en:
Francine is 34 years old and has one child, aged 10, who is currently in school. She works with her husband selling goods in a general store that they have run for eight years. 

She would like a loan to buy bread, soda, lotions, cooking oil, rice, beans and sorghum to sell in her store. Francine will use any profits to create savings for her future.

loans.use: To buy more bread, sodas, lotions and cooking oil to sell.

loans.name: Zakia

texts.en: Zakia is married and has one child, age 1. Zakia sells bread. She would like a loan to buy more baking powder, sugar, and baking items to make more bread to sell. With the profits, she will reinvest in her business and create savings for her future. She would love to see her business prosper.

loans.use: To buy more baking powder, sugar for making breads.

loans.name: Gevorg

texts.en: Gevorg rents a booth in the city market, where he sews and sells clothing. Due to the high quality of his work, Gevorg has attracted a large number of clients. In order to maintain the high quality of his clothing, Gevorg needs to purchase a new sewing machine, as the old one doesn't sew properly anymore. With the loan, Gevorg also plans to purchase some new clothing to sell. He will develop his business and increase his working capital, allowing him to pay for his children's education and ensure a sustainable future for his family. Gevorg lives with his wife, school-age son, and two student daughters.

loans.use: to buy a sewing machine.

loans.name: Joemar

texts.en:
This is Joemar, age 41, a resident of the Tanza municipality in Cavite Province in the Philippines. He is single, but he works hard to sustain himself and his family and to continually provide income for his everyday expenses.

Joemar operates a food stall wherein he sells fish balls. Fish balls are somewhat flattened in shape and often made with cuttlefish meat. In the Philippines, fish balls are commonly sold on street sides. They are served skewered and can be dipped in different kinds of sauces. Joemar’s other products include squid balls and quail eggs. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. He earns a minimum of 200 PHP in daily sales.

To help him continue the operation of his business, he is requesting a 9,000 PHP loan. He will be using the loan to buy more fish ball products and the other ingredients needed in his business. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business.

Joemar hopes to be able to expand his business soon, and he dreams of having a bright future for himself and for his family. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week, allowing him to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, to build social capital, and to repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy more fish ball products and the other ingredients needed in his business.

loans.name: Odette

texts.en: Odette is married with 4 children ages 8 to 15. All of them are currently in school. Odette owns a restaurant which she has run for 16 years. She would like a loan to increase her inventory of food in the restaurant. Any profits will be used to reinvest in her business. In the future, she would like to see her restaurant prosper.

loans.use: To add more foodstuffs in the restaurant

loans.name: Roberto

texts.en:
This is Roberto, 41, resident of Tanza, Cavite, Philippines. He is single but works hard to sustain himself and continually provide income for his everyday expenses.

Roberto operates a food stall wherein he sells fish balls. In the Philippines, fish balls are commonly sold on street sides; it is served skewered and can be dipped with different kinds of sauces. Fish balls are somewhat flat in shape and often made with the meat of a cuttlefish. His other products include squid balls and quail eggs.  His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. He earns a minimum of Php 200 in sales every day.

To help him continue operations of his business, he is requesting a Php 9,000 loan. He will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of fish ball products and other ingredients needed in his business. He expects a boost in her business income as he expands his business.

Roberto hopes to be able to expand soon. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional stocks of fish ball products and other ingredients needed in his business

loans.name: Hasmik

texts.en: Hasmik is engaged in an agricultural business. She keeps livestock and cultivates land. Hasmik would like to develop farming, for which she needs a sufficient financial investment. With the requested loan, Hasmik plans to purchase livestock. Expansion of the farm will help Hasmik get more income and renovate her house. House renovation means improved living conditions for Hasmik and her family. Hasmik lives together with her husband and two children.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy 13 head of piglets and 10 sacks of feed for her project.

loans.name: Sinoko Farmers Group

texts.en:
Linet is the facilitator of the Sinoko Farmers group. Linet and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Linet and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

She joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough to ensure food security for her family and to have farm inputs in time for planting. In the recent 2011 season, Linet had an excellent maize yield harvesting 24 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Linet was only able to harvest eight bags of maize on one acre of land.

With income from her maize sales, Linet will save for medication for her family members and educate her children.

In 2012, the members of Sinoko Farmers group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

The photograph shows Linet with her group members and standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Yagbe Tn1 Group

texts.fr: YAGBE TN1 est un groupement constitué de onze personnes et dont la représentante (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) se nomme Chantal. Les membres du groupement vivent dans le même quartier. Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de roulement,ce groupement sollicite pour la deuxième fois, un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Chantal est âgée de 39 ans et vit au Bénin. Chantal est mariée à un chauffeur du nom de Moïse. Le couple a quatre enfants tous à leur charge.Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Chantal subvient ensemble avec son mari aux besoins du ménage. Chantal n'a jamais été à l'école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Chantal mène comme activité la vente de charbon de bois et des chaussures de façon secondaire. Chantal achète ses produits au Bénin et au Togo et les revend à son domicile et aussi par le système de distribution. Chantal exerce cette activité depuis seize ans. Ce deuxième prêt permettra certainement à Chantal et aux autres membres du groupement YAGBE TN1, de rehausser le niveau de leur activité et d’accroître leur clientèle et leur revenu.
texts.en: YAGBE TN1 is a group of eleven people whose representative (with her hand raised in the photo) is called Chantal. The group members live in the same neighbourhood. In order to increase their working capital, this group is seeking a second loan with Alidé. Chantal is 39 years old and lives in Benin. Chantal is married to a driver called Moïse. The couple have four children all living at home. All the children are school educated. Chantal, together with her husband, meets the family's basic needs. Chantal never went to school. To meet her needs and those of the children, Chantal is a seller of charcoal and, to a lesser extent, shoes. Chantal buys her products in Benin and Togo and resells them from home, and also via a distribution system. Chantal has been doing this for sixteen years. This second loan will allow Chantal and the other members of the YAGBE TN1 group to grow their business, and to increase their customer base and their income.

loans.use: to buy bags of charcoal and shoes

loans.name: Lina

texts.en: Lina trades in clothing from a rented booth in the city market. In order to meet her clients' demand before the coming New Year season, Lina would like to increase her clothing assortment. With the help of this loan, Lina will increase sales and receive more business income. This will allow Lina to sustain her family and improve the family's living conditions.

loans.use: to pay for clothing

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
53-year-old Corazon earns a living buying and selling fresh fruits and vegetables. She is from Baclayon, Bohol. Corazon also manages a rice farm. Corazon sells her produce at her town's market. Each month, Corazon earns 10000 PHP with her business.

Corazon has requested a loan to purchase seeds and more fruits to sell. Corazon hopes for her business to grow.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and more fruits to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase metals

loans.name: Lea

texts.en:
This is Lea, 47, resident of Tanza, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Luis, a driver, and they have a child. She, together with her husband and child, manage their own household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Lea oversees operations of their vehicle rental business. They have 1 van that they offer to be rented for special trips or for people who need vehicles as service. They provide their services within the city & nearby provinces. Aside from this, Lea also manages a soap making business and computer rental business. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of  450 Philippine Pesos (PHP)in profit every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php10, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy spare parts and for maintenance of her van. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Lea dreams of giving her child a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she hopes to have her own house and lot. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for the spare parts and maintenance of her van.

loans.name: Mwambuli Women Group

texts.en:
Enos is the facilitator of Mwambuli Women group. Enos and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Enos is a father of three children. He joined One Acre Fund to grow enough in order to ensure food security for his family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Enos had an excellent maize yield harvesting 15 bags on 3/4 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Enos was only able to harvest three bags of maize on 3/4 acres of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Enos and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from his maize sales, Enos will educate his children, build a house and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Mwambuli Women group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land. He is pictured in the photograph with his group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Heghine

texts.en:
Heghine is engaged in agriculture. Unable to find sufficient financial means to develop the business, Heghine has applied for a loan. With the requested loan, Heghine plans to purchase livestock and seeds. With the help of this loan, Heghine expects to increase her income, which will allow her to expand her farm in the future. 

Additional income also means improved living conditions for Heghine and her family. Heghine lives with her husbund, a child and her father.

loans.use: to pay for livestock and seeds

loans.name: Rodolfo

texts.en:
This is Rodolfo, 44, a resident of Tanza, Cavite, Philippines. He is married to Sencia, a housekeeper and mother to their three children. Their eldest child is already in high school while the other two are in elementary school. Rodolfo, together with his wife, manages their own household while operating the business. He works hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Rodolfo operates a rolling store. His rolling store is basically a small household products store which retails plastic containers, dippers, pails, plastic flowers and basins to the local neighborhood. He drives the rolling store around the local community. He buys supplies at wholesale prices and sells by the piece. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. He earns a minimum of Php 800 in sales every day.

To help him continue operations of his business, he is requesting a Php 12,000 loan. He will use the loan to buy pails, plasticware, hangers, clothes pins, plastic flowers and other items to expand his product inventory. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business.

Rodolfo hopes that his business will continue to be successful and dreams of giving his children a bright future. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship members to share stories of his work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To stock for his store

loans.name: Raquel

texts.en:
Raquel is 24 years old and single. She has a 2-year-old child.

Raquel sells accessories and school supplies to the people in her community. She has had this business for 5 years. Each month, Raquel earns 6000 PHP running her store.

Raquel has requested this loan to buy more items to sell. She hopes to expand her store in the future.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell

loans.name: Zahida's Group

texts.en:
Zahida has applied for a loan from KIVA partner Asasah for her husband's transport business. Her husband purchased an auto-rickshaw a few years ago on installment and wants to payoff the remaining installments all at once.
By doing this, the auto-rickshaw will become his property and he will be able to run his transport business better.
Zahida is a housewife and performs her duties by staying at home. She is the mother of 3 sons and a daughter. All of them are enrolled in a nearby school and getting their education.
Zahida is very hopeful that an investment will help her husband in his business and her family will be able to enjoy better living conditions as a result of it.

loans.use: To pay off the installments of an auto-rickshaw

loans.name: Dip C Group

texts.en:
William is the facilitator of Dip C group. William and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

 William is a father of three children. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, William had a good maize yield, harvesting 6 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  he was only able to harvest 1 1/2 bags of maize on ½ an acre of land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to William and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, William will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Dip C group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land. 

William is pictured in the photograph with his group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Hoan's Group

texts.en:
Ms Hoan is 41 years old, married and has two children who both go to school. She joined Seda from Centre in 2010 and is the leader of this 5 member group. Her first loan was used to invest in growing rice and raising pigs. She repaid this loan. Her total income is 3.000.000 Vietnamdong ( VNĐ). She wants to borrow 5.152.000 VNĐ to purchase pigs and pig feed. 
 
Other group members:
 Ms Nhuân, 37 years old, married, borrowing 5.152.000 VNĐ loan to buy wood for producing furniture for sale. 
 Ms Nghị, 38 years old, married, borrowing 5.152.000 VNĐ loan to buy wood for producing tables and chairs for sale .
 Ms Thưc, 33 years old, married, borrowing 5.152.000 VNĐ to purchase feed for pigs and timber to produce tables and chairs.
 Ms Chiên, 31 years old, married, borrowing 5.152.000 VNĐ to buy food for pigs.

loans.use: to buy pigs and pigfeed

loans.name: Mbomele Group

texts.en:
John is the facilitator of the Mbomele group. John and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

John takes care of two children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, John had an excellent maize yield, harvesting 8 ½ bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  John was only able to harvest 3 ½ bags of maize on ½ an acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to John and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, John will save for the future in order to hire another plot of farmland for more production and he will invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Mbomele group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, John is pictured with his group members. Standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Neang

texts.en: Mr. Neang, 33, is a humble farmer who has been residing in Kompong Cham province, Cambodia. He has a life partner in his wife who is in the same business: cultivating rice crops. This couple is blessed with 3 single, dependent children. Mr. Neang is a diligent father. He also sometimes works as a construction worker with his building team, earning approximately $2.00 per day. Mr. Neang has requested this loan to buy a second-hand motorcycle for use in his family. This loan will improve his living conditions. In the future, he wants to see his children get a good education. That is why he has to try hard to save some money for their education.

loans.use: to buy a second-hand motorcycle.

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
46-year-old Imelda earns a living providing mobile prepaid credit and selling softdrinks. She has had this business for 10 years. Imelda earns 10000 PHP each month. She plans to use her loan to buy more mobile prepaid credit and soft drinks to sell.

Imelda works hard to support her family of a husband and a 3-year-old child. One of her goals is to save for her child's education.

loans.use: to buy more mobile prepaid credit and soft drinks to sell

loans.name: Florife

texts.en:
This is Florife, age 52, a resident of Dasmariñas City in Cavite Province in the Philippines. She is married to Melchor, her business partner, and she has three children. She, together with her husband and children, manage their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Florife operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which sells groceries, toiletries, and beverages to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one packet of shampoo, 5 PHP of cooking oil, or an egg. Florife earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them retail. Aside from this, she also sells personal products for additional income. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 600 PHP in daily sales.

To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting a 27,000 PHP loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Florife hopes her business will grow in the coming years, and she dreams of being able to give her children a good, high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, allowing her to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, to build social capital, and to repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Halima

texts.ru: Халима трудолюбивая и добросовестная женщина. Она замужем, ей 54 года. Более 5 лет она занимается купле- продажей детской и женской одежды. Она приобретает товар на рынке близлежащего города и продает на своей торговой точке. Её торговая точка находится около городского центрального рынка. Халима хочет расширить свой бизнес и пополнить свой оборотный капитал. С этой целью она запрашивает займ в размере 8000 Сомони. Она надеется на вашу помощь и заранее благодарит вас за вашу поддержку.
texts.en: Halima is a hardworking and conscientious woman. She is married and 54 years old. For more than five years she has been in the business of buying and selling children's and women's clothing. She obtains the goods at the market in a nearby town and sells them at her own shop. Her shop is located near the city's central market. Halima wants to expand her business and augment her working capital. With this in mind, she is requesting a loan of 8.000 somoni. She looks forward to your help and thanks you in advance for your support.

loans.use: to purchase inventory of children's and women's clothing

loans.name: Faulu Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Faulu Group in Western Kenya! Patrick is the facilitator of the group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Patrick is a father of two children. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Patrick had a very good maize yield, harvesting 13 bags on 3/4 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, he was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize on 3/4 acre of land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Patrick  and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Patrick will educate his children, ensure food security, and invest in livestock rearing.

 In 2012, the members of Faulu group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

Patrick is pictured with his group members in the photograph.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia is married and has 3 daughters and 2 sons. Except the youngest one, all are getting their education by attending a nearby school. 

Razia is very supportive and helps to support her husband's animal selling business.  Her husband purchases sheep and goats at a young age for low prices, raises them and sells to butchers to make a profit.  Razia takes care of the cattle by giving them food and keeping their living place clean.

She also performs house work very well.
 
Razia has applied for a loan from KIVA partner Asasah for the further improvement of her husband’s business.  With the loan investment, he will buy goats and sheep.

He has been operating his business for many years and Razia is hopeful that an investment will be productive.

loans.use: to buy goats and sheep for animal sales business.

loans.name: Celestino

texts.pt:
Nasceu no Distrito de Manhiça, Província de Maputo, Sul de Moçambique, casado e pai de 5  filhos todos ainda frequentam a Escola. Fez a 4ª classe e parou por falta de condições financeiras pela parte dos pais. Vive na casa propria com a sua familia e não sustenta mais ninguem. 

Saiu de Manhiça para oDistrito de Boane aprocura de melhores condições de vida, é carpinteiro ha mais de 31 anos e tem um rendimento de cerca de 15.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e poupa algum na sua conta bancaria(BIM).
Já teve emprestimos noutros bancos(TSHUMA) e conseguiu pagar sem dificuldades, conheceu a Hluvuku atravez de uma amigo que tambem é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu segundo emprestimo na Hluvuku no valor de 26.350.00mt, com qual pretende comprar material de construção para dar continuidade a obra da sua casa(areia, cimento, pedra, ferro e outros)
Compromete se a pagar devidamente e no futuro pretende terminar a obra da sua casa e comprar uma viatura para o transporte da madeira para a sua carpintaria, para tal tenciona solicitar mais emprestimos a Hluvuku.
texts.en:
Celestino was born in the District of Manhiça, in the Province of Maputo in the South of Mozambique. He’s married and the father of 5 children who are still all at School. He completed 4th grade and didn’t continue his education due to his parents’ lack of financial means. He lives in his own house with his family and doesn’t support anyone else.

He left Manhiça for the District of Boane looking for better living conditions. He has been a carpenter for more than 31 years and has a monthly income of around 15,000.00 meticals (MZN) which he spends on household expenditures and saves in his bank account (BIM).

Celestino has had loans from other banks (TSHUMA) which he has been able to pay back without difficulties and he came to know Hluvuku through a friend who is also a client of this institution. This is his second loan with Hluvuku, for the amount of 26,350.00 MZN with which he intends to purchase construction materials in order to continue building his home (sand, cement, stone, iron and others). He commits to paying off the loan and in future he intends to finish off his house and purchase a vehicle for transporting wood to his carpentry workshop. To this end, he intends to solicit further loans from Hluvuku.

loans.use: purchase construction materials in order to continue building his home (sand, cement, stone, iron and others)

loans.name: Jitegemee Shg Group

texts.en:
Amos is the facilitator of the Jitegemee SHG group. Amos and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Amos takes care of four children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to have additional maize profits to educate his children. In the recent 2011 season, Amos had a very good maize yield, harvesting 5 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Amos was only able to harvest 1 ½ bags of maize on ½ an acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Amos and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Amos will educate his children and save for the future.

In 2012, the members of Jitegemee SHG group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Amos is pictured with his group members, and the person standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Jamiyan

texts.en: Mr. Jamiyan, age 29, sells electronics in a supermarket called “Bumbugur,” and he lives with his wife and son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He has been in this business since 2000 and has gained enough experience in his business field. He usually obtains his inventory from a certified Japanese electronics distributor. Lately, his business income has decreased notably due to a deficiency of inventory. During the last two months, he has sold almost 85-90% of his inventory. There will be a lack of inventory to sell next month. Therefore, he should increase his working capital immediately. The loan he is taking will be used to purchase a larger number of electronics to increase the inventory for more sales.

loans.use: to purchase a larger number of electronics to increase the inventory for more sales.

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
This is Joan, 43, a resident of Dasmarinas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Dennis, a factory worker, and is mother to their child. She and her husband manage their own household while operating the business. She works hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Joan operates a door mat business. Her products are small rugs and larger doormats. She makes door mats out of excess textiles that she buys from the factory. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, they are one of the most common products that can be bought - sometimes even from a peddler while you are traveling down the highway. She sells her products directly to her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php200 every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php8,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Joan hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams of being able to give her family a good future through her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Toshmat

texts.ru: Тошмат более трех лет занимается купле -продажей скота. Он трудолюбивый и добросовестный человек, он женат и ответственный отец четверых детей. Тошмат хорошо ухаживает за скотом и дома имеет большой участок земли для содержания скота. У него имеется 2 голов крупнорогатого скота, 2 теленка и 10 голов овец. В запасе имеет корм  на зиму. Кроме того он занимается перевозкой пассажиров, то есть услугами такси. От этих видов бизнеса он получает хорошую прибыль. Тошмат хочет расширить свой бизнес и для этого хочет купить скот. С этой целью он запрашивает займ в размере 2000$ США.
texts.en: Toshmat has been buying and selling cattle for more than three years. He is a hardworking, conscientious man. He is married and the responsible father of four children. Toshmat takes care of his cattle well and has a large piece of land at home for them. He has 2 cattle, 2 calves and 10 sheep. In stock, he has food for winter. Besides this he also offers taxi services. From this work he earns a good income. Toshmat wants to expand his business and for this he would like to purchase cattle. To this end, he is requesting a loan of $2,000.

loans.use: buy cattle and expand his business

loans.name: Mangule

texts.pt:
Nasceu no Distrito de Boane, Província de Maputo, Sul de Moçambique, solteira e mãe de 2  filhos dos quais um ainda frequenta a Escola. Fez a 7ª classe e parou por falta de condições financeiras pela parte dos pais. Vive na casa propria com a sua familia e não sustenta mais ninguem. 

É cabelereira ha mais de 15 anos e dona do salão e tem um rendimento de cerca de 5.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e poupa algum na sua conta bancaria(BIM).
Nunca teve emprestimos noutros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku atravez de uma amigo que tambem é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu quinto emprestimo na Hluvuku no valor de 20.000.00mt, com qual pretende comprar material de construção para dar continuidade a obra da sua casa(chapas, areia, cimento, pedra,  e outros).Os primeiros emprestimos foram de: 7.000.00mt, 8.000.00mt, 13.000.00mt, e 13.000.00mt,todos para habitação.
Compromete se a pagar devidamente e no futuro pretende terminar a obra da sua casa e construir uma Pastelaria para aumentar o seu rendimento, para tal tenciona solicitar mais emprestimos a Hluvuku.
texts.en:
Mangule was born in the District of Boane, in the Province of Maputo in the South of Mozambique. She’s single and the mother of 2 children, one of whom still attends School. She completed 4th grade and didn’t continue her education due to her parents’ lack of financial means. She lives in her own house with her family and doesn’t support anyone else.

Mangule has been a hairdresser for more than 15 years, as well as the owner of a salon and has a monthly income of around 5,000.00 meticals (MZN) which she spends on household expenditures and saves in her bank account (BIM).

She has never had loans from other banks and she came to know Hluvuku through a friend who is also a client of this institution. This is her fifth loan from Hluvuku, for 20,000.00 MZN, with which she intends to purchase construction materials to continue the build of her home (plates, sand, cement, stone and others). Her first loans were for: 7,000.00 MZN, 8,000.00 MZN, 13,000.00 MZN and 13,000.00 MZN, all of which she used for her house.

Mangule commits to paying off her loan and in the future intends to complete the construction of her home and build a cake & pastry shop in order to increase her income. To this end, she expects to solicit further loans from Hluvuku.

loans.use: purchase construction materials to continue the build of her home (plates, sand, cement, stone and others)

loans.name: Tin

texts.en: From Kompong Cham province, Mrs.Tin, 38, has spent most of her life cultivating rice crops. Her husband is also involved in this activity. Together, they are able to earn a profit of $3.50 each day but this is barely enough to satisfy Tin’s family because there are 7 single children who live on her income. Mrs.Tin wants to improve her living conditions and is always looking for a good chance to pursue a profitable business. Mrs. Tin would like to request some funds from Kiva to buy a second-hand motorcycle to enable her son to start providing motorcycle transportation. She is thankful for any help from lenders.

loans.use: to buy a second-hand motorcycle for her son to start providing motorcycle services.

loans.name: Otgonbaatar

texts.en:
Mr.Otgonbaatar, 29, runs an inter-city passenger transportation business in Mongolia. He has been doing this for 3 years and already has permanent customers. He carries one passenger for 5 buks from city to city. Otgonbaatar lives with his wife and 4 children in a boundary district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. 
Recently he bought a small piece of land in a suburban area of Ulaanbaatar with his business earnings. It is located in a good place with a healthy environment. 
Now he is planning to build a small house on his new land in the spring of 2012. Therefore, he is starting preparations by purchasing building materials. The loan he is taking will be used to purchase building materials needed to build his family house as soon as possible.

loans.use: To purchase building materials to build his family house

loans.name: Cremilde

texts.pt:
Nasceu na Província de Inhambane, Sul de Moçambique, solteira e mãe de 1  filho ainda bebé. Fez o nivel secundário e parou por falta de condições financeiras pela parte dos pais. Vive na casa propria com a sua familia e não sustenta mais ninguem. 

Saiu de Inhambane para o Distrito de Boane a procura de emprego, é recepcionista ha mais de 5 anos na Ara Sul e tem um salario de 5.037.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e poupa algum na sua conta bancaria(BIM).
Nunca teve emprestimos noutros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku atravez de uma amigo que tambem é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu primeiro emprestimo na Hluvuku no valor de 24.000.00mt, com qual pretende comprar material de construção para dar continuidade a obra da sua casa(barrotes, chapas, cimento, pedra,  e outros).
Compromete se a pagar devidamente e no futuro pretende terminar a obra da sua casa e mobiliar, para tal tenciona solicitar mais emprestimos a Hluvuku.
texts.en:
Cremilde was born in the Inhambane Province in southern Mozambique.  She is single and has one son who is still a baby.  She attended high school but did not finish because her parents did not have the financial resources.  She owns the home where she lives with her family and she doesn't support anyone else.  

Cremilde left Inhambane for the Boane district to look for work.  She has been a receptionist for more than 5 years at Ara Sul, and she has a monthly salary of 5.037.00mt which she uses for household expenses and savings in her bank account (BIM).

She has never had a loan with other banks.  She learned about Hluvuku through a friend who is also a client.  This is her first loan with Hluvuku, in the amount of 24.000.00mt, which she plans to use to purchase materials to continue construction on her home (beams, metal panels, stones, etc.).

She promises to make her payments on schedule.  In the future, she plans to complete construction and furnish her home, and she will request additional loans from Hluvuku for that purpose.

loans.use: to purchase materials to continue construction on her home (beams, metal panels, cement, stone, etc.)

loans.name: Jolly

texts.en:
This is Jolly, 29, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Julius, a technician, and is mother to two children. She, along with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. She works hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses. 

Jolly maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk and Marikina Shoe Exchange. A customer's order is paid for in cash by the dealer and then supplied to the customer on one-month-to-pay credit terms. Dealer prices are lower than those in the catalogue: these are the profits that dealers retain as income. She also makes foot rugs for additional income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 1,500 in sales every week.

To help her continue business operations she is requesting a Php10,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy merchandise and orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Jolly dreams of being able to give all her children a good, high quality education through her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for merchandise needed in her business.

loans.name: Zarif

texts.ru: Зариф целеустремленный и трудолюбивый семьянин. Он женат и имеет двоих детей. С этой целью обеспечения семьи он начал заниматься купле- продажей скота и более 30 лет занимается этим делом и имеет богатый опыт. Зариф на данный момент имеет  крупный рогатый скот и 6 голов овец. Зариф запрашивает займ для покупки скота для того, чтобы расширить свой бизнес и получать хорошую прибыль для улучшения благосостояния семьи.
texts.en: Zarif is a purposeful and hardworking family man. He is married and has two children. He started buying and selling cattle with the purpose to provide for his family more than 30 years ago and has rich experience in this business. At this time Zarif has large horned cattle and six heads of sheep. Zarif is asking for a loan to buy cattle so he can grow his business and make more profit for better living conditions for his family.
